central sulcus it goes down and on the
inferior end over here we have the
lateral cerebral fissure and posteriorly
we have the parietal occipital fissure
that separates the parietal lobe from
the occipital lobe
now the parietal lobe is primarily
involved in perceiving and processing
somatosensory events so we're talking
about things like touch and temperature
and body position and pain so the term
that we use for body position is
proprioception and the term that we use
for pain is nociception it's appropriate
ception in our susceptance are also
involved in the processing of the

post central sources on the posterior
and of that gyrus and the function of
that gyrus is basically receiving some
aesthetic information so we're talking
about kinesthetic and tactile
information kinesthetic meaning body

that information comes in and it goes to
the post central gyrus and there's some
processing that happens there for us to
be able to recognize movement
of body and when we get touched we can

now of course the left half of the brain
so the left post central gyrus is gonna
be getting information from the right

central gyrus is gonna be receiving
information from the left side of the
body not only that but it's also what we
call so mater topically so let me write
that here
so mato topically organized what that
means is specific parts of the post
central gyrus are gonna receive
information from specific parts of the
body and for example if we are looking
at the face and head the information
that's coming from the face and the head
are gonna be processing the most
inferior parts of the post central gyrus
and as we go more superior we're gonna
be starting to get input from the upper
limbs and if we go more medial so we're
going more towards the center of the
brain we're gonna be getting information
from the lower limbs so it's so mater
topically organized so specific parts of
this gyrus gets information from
specific parts of the body and you're
gonna see that a lot in the different
parts of the brain so post central gyrus
we spoke about that and then we have the
superior parietal lobule and of course
that's going to be superior and that
what that does is it integrates sensory

means it's inside or in between
